channel.title: NBA.com: News
channel.description: NBA.com delivers the latest news, video, and scores from around the NBA league.

item.title: Metta World Peace remains sorry for pain he inflicted on Pacers' organization
item.description: A lot of turbulent water has gone under the bridge since the ugly brawl between the Pistons and Pacers that eventually spilled into the stands at the Palace of Auburn Hills.

item.title: Stephen Curry on Ray Allen: 'Greatest shooter ever'
item.description: On any given night you can flip on the channel where the Golden State are playing and see Stephen Curry make another shot that practically defies description.

item.title: Blogtable: Is LeBron James one of top 5 greatest players ever?
Blogtable: Which player is destined to become a perennial All-Star?
Blogtable: What's your view of Warriors after their first four games?
Shootaround (Nov. 2) -- Anthony Davis wants Pelicans to right ship quickly
item.description: Davis frustrated by Pelicans' winless start | Kobe says he doesn't miss playing | Durant opens up about Westbrook | Warriors upset over Cavs' party prop

item.title: Aaron Gordon warms up for dunk contest vs. Sixers
item.description: A breakaway dunk for most people was Aaron Gordon of the Magic warming up for the dunk contest at the 2017 All-Star game.

item.title: Ray Allen, the top 3-point shooter in NBA history, announces retirement
item.description: MIAMI (AP) -- Ray Allen won championships in Boston and Miami, made one of the most memorable shots in NBA Finals history and has more 3-pointers than anyone who ever played in the league.

item.title: Jazz's Alec Burks out indefinitely after left ankle surgery
item.description: SALT LAKE CITY (AP) -- The Utah Jazz say forward Alec Burks underwent arthroscopic surgery on his left ankle Tuesday and is out indefinitely.

item.title: Bulls' Michael Carter-Williams out 4-6 weeks with bruise to left knee
item.description: Michael Carter-Williams was a late addition to the Chicago Bulls' roster, arriving in the Oct. 17 trade that sent Tony Snell to the Milwaukee Bucks. As such, he had much to learn in a short amount of time in prepping for the backup point guard role behind Rajon Rondo.
